Structure Manager: Creating a new top-level section after an existing section is only possible when existing section is collapsed

comments.body: Historic note: PUL devs added the collapse option to allow for a workaround to this issue.

First steps:

1. Wireframe/Re-vision for the Structure Manager to allow for a different UI for nesting and creating sections.

figgy.title: Structure Manager: Selecting a nested item should not also select its parent

comments.body: We need to research this more. It may not be that the parent is selected, it may be about the cascade of selectors. Perhaps new CSS features could help address this?

figgy.title: Order Manager: allow for automated labeling without page numbering

comments.body:
Make another ticket to address the "false" issue when a non-number or roman numeral is entered. Perhaps leave the formatting/non-alphanumerics alone when auto numbering?

Possibly a further user observation test? What was their first instinct when trying to solve this?

figgy.title: Arabic section titles are not appearing as Right To Left in Universal Viewer

comments.body: potentially relevant UV ticket https://github.com/UniversalViewer/universalviewer/issues/299

Follow up with users about whether the title in UV is RTL, but should also be justified right. UV has no `dir` attribute on the element. Is there a way to tell the viewer that this is RTL. Setting `dir='rtl'` in the TOC seems to do the right thing. However, there's often mixed languages in the TOC, so we need to apply it directly to the section labels. 

Things to explore, in order:

1. Can IIIF support RTL in text labels? (look at spec, ask in slack)
2. Can UV support RTL in section titles? The answer is yes, if we can assign a language to the label that's an RTL language. (we can test with a mock manifest)
3. We need to be able to assign `lang` value in Structure Manager. We define the language in the metadata values, and you can see that it works in the metadata panel of the UV. 

Note: Rails Gem currently auto-assumes RTL or LTR (not language) based on the unicode character range.

Other implementation possibilities:
- Do the above and also try to have the structure manager provide a best guess for the language and allow users to override.
- Propose a way for iiif to allow us to give a rtl designation to a label (then we can leverage the rails gem mentioned in note above)
- implement something in UV that's similar to the rails gem (referenced in note above)
mentioned by @eliotjordan https://github.com/jtoy/cld

openpublishing.title: Added Japanese language file (translations to be added by admins)
Improve search feature while in Japanese mode

comments.body:
## Update
The keyword search doesn't work in Japanese language mode with any keywords provided for this ticket. I used the keywords available in this ticket. I tried an author and that did work.

## Update 
The search feature works for a known author of one of the submissions and for a title (or part of a title) as displayed on OJS. (I had copied/pasted from a known record into the search feature.) It doesn't work for the keywords provided by our Japanese language expert. I also tried the search feature with copy/pasted random characters and groupings of characters from the contents of a known publication in this journal. Those terms also didn't work.

ops-catchall.title: lib-sftp creation of ansible managed server

comments.body: make AD users have r/w

I have an example patron who can be used to debug this issue. We'll probably have to trace the call the form makes to get patron information and then pass this patrons info over to replicate the problem. When I pass this patron' netid to the bibdata route that provides patron data I also get an error at https://bibdata.princeton.edu/patron/{patron netid}.
I notice this error lists catalog-staging not prod, is that correct?
This page loads fine for me in prod when I'm logged in.
Yes, the honeybadger error was limited to catalog-staging1 and catalog-staging2 (sorry, I should have made that clear in the ticket)
